choices.B: The dynamic SQL statement retrieves rows into records.
choices.C: You do not know how many columns a select statement will return, or what their data types will.
choices.A: The SELECT list is not known until run time.
choices.D: You must use the % found SQL cursor attribute after issuing a dynamic SQL statement that is an insert or update statement.

discussion.content:
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/appdev.112/e25519/dynamic.htm#LNPLS01108

“You must use the DBMS_SQL package to run a dynamic SQL statement when you do not know either of these until run time:
SELECT list
What placeholders in a SELECT or DML statement must be bound

In these situations, you must use native dynamic SQL instead of the DBMS_SQL package:
The dynamic SQL statement retrieves rows into records.
You want to use the SQL cursor attribute %FOUND, %ISOPEN, %NOTFOUND, or %ROWCOUNT after issuing a dynamic SQL statement that is an INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, MERGE, or single-row SELECT statement.”

questions.question_text: Identify two situations where the DBMS_SQL package should be used. (Choose two.)

Which statement is true about the execution of the code?

choices.C: The execution fails and throws exceptions if no employee with EMPLOYEE_ID 115 is found.
choices.D: The execution is successful, but it displays an incorrect output if no employee with EMPLOYEE_ID 115 is found.
choices.B: The execution is successful even if there is no employee with EMPLOYEE_ID 115.
choices.A: The execution fails because of the misplaced else clause.

choices.A: JONES executes the procedure with definer's rights.
choices.B: JONES executes the procedure with invoker's rights.
choices.C: SCOTT should grant only the execute privilege for the procedure to JONES.
choices.D: SCOTT should grant both the execute privilege for the procedure and insert privilege for the table to JONES.

choices.B: because the lexicon variable is not visible in procedure ADD_ENTRY
choices.C: because the lexicon variable is not initialized in procedure wording
choices.D: because the WORD_LIST parameter in out mode cannot be of a record data type
choices.A: because the WORD_LIST variable is not visible in procedure wording

discussion.content: option B is wrong, as local variable can be visible inside local procedure, if they are declared before the procedure inside anonymous block.

Yes, A is the correct answer. 
Explanation - the statement - DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE(word_list.word) will fail as wrod_list is a formal parameter which is visible only to the PROCEDURE add_entry
more exactly word_list is a pararmeter not a variable

A - false because we don't have bind variables (the ones with colon)
B - true because every statement needs parsing
C - true because every select needs fetch
D - true because every insert/update/delete needs execute

Yes, the correct answer is BCD.
Explanation - Since there is no bind variable only A. Bind is not performed.
